stream_context.summary: Kaze works on the 'Board the Platforms' retro section for Course 11. The main focus is creating a visually impressive 3D version of the original Smash 64 background, iterating from a flawed concept to a successful one using a custom skybox. He also begins blocking out the level's platforming and live-adjusts the game's camera controls based on viewer feedback. This is his first stream multistreaming to both Twitch and YouTube.

development_findings.summary: The retro section for Course 11, Oily Boily Bay, is a 3D recreation of the 'Board the Platforms' stage from Super Smash Bros. 64.
development_findings.quote: The retro game here will be... Board the Platforms! It'll be like Mario State from Board the Platforms in Smash 64, but in 3D.

development_findings.summary: Kaze decided against a simple 2D background, opting for a more complex and impressive 3D parallax effect with multiple layers of rotating geometric shapes to recreate the Smash 64 aesthetic.
development_findings.quote: I think what we're gonna do is we're gonna have one layer of these squares here that are actually there in space... So it's gonna look like this, but a lot better.

development_findings.summary: After an initial failed attempt with individual transparent planes, Kaze devised a more performant and visually effective method for the background by cutting shapes out of a massive UV sphere, effectively creating a custom skybox.
development_findings.quote: We will make a UV sphere... We're just gonna draw the squares onto here... and then we're gonna invert our selection and remove everything else.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is producing a video about the concept of 'good enough' or pragmatically 'bad' code, and has code in the project that will serve as an example.
development_findings.quote: I'm making a new video on when bad code is actually good and that's gonna be part of the video.

development_findings.summary: A graphical glitch inside a pipe was diagnosed as a misplaced lava bubble, which Kaze suspects might be a symptom of the level approaching its memory limits.
development_findings.quote: I think that's a lava bubble, I think there's a lava bubble spawning inside the pipe... We might be running low on memory in this level.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is considering replacing a planned 'music level' theme with a 'Yoshi school' theme after a chat suggestion sparked his interest.
development_findings.quote: I feel like a Yoshi school instead of a music level, that has potential.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is using the block-out technique to design the platforming layout for the 'Board the Platforms' area, focusing on gameplay flow with simple shapes before committing to final art.
development_findings.quote: I'm just gonna Smash together some random platforms and then after that, we're gonna see how to make them look fun. This is the block out technique basically.

development_findings.summary: In response to viewer feedback, Kaze live-adjusted the camera's d-pad controls, tweaking the acceleration curve to find a better balance between small, precise adjustments and broader camera sweeps.
development_findings.quote: Small d-pad adjustments shouldn't have sine interpolation and should just be linear.

development_findings.summary: The remaining four main level themes are planned to be Wild West Valley, a music/Yoshi school level, an oversized casino level, and a comic-based world.

context_findings.summary: Kaze's personal motivation for weightlifting is based on the challenge of progressive improvement, a philosophy that may extend to his game development.
context_findings.quote: I just like the challenge of like increasing the weight.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is self-aware about creating content for engagement ('clout chasing') but presents it with a layer of ironic detachment, suggesting he believes his established audience is in on the joke.
context_findings.quote: Dude, do you think being honest about being a cloud chaser makes being a cloud chaser less bad? Because I don't subscribe to cloud chasers. I'm just a piece of shit.

context_findings.summary: Kaze acknowledges that his full-time job at Gears for Breakfast significantly limits the time he can dedicate to community content and side projects.
context_findings.quote: If I didn't have a full-time job, I would definitely make a supercut like that.

context_findings.summary: Kaze values precision and conciseness in communication, which likely influences his direct and technical approach to explaining his development process.
context_findings.quote: I think that when you speak you should be precise and you should be concise those are the two qualities i value the most in speech.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is conscious of his professional obligations and the legal agreements from his job at Gears for Breakfast, to the point of it appearing in his nightmares.
context_findings.quote: I had a nightmare today that I accidentally broke our NDA and Gus Fring came to me and interrogated me about me breaking my NDA, that was fucking scary.

context_findings.quote: I think Studio Ghibli movies are kinda really just very boring. Don't like them at all.

context_findings.summary: Kaze had an extremely negative experience playing Lego Fortnite during a company game-playing session, contrasting with his colleagues who enjoyed it.
context_findings.quote: I'm really glad I got paid for that time because... That was fucking miserable. I would not ever play that fucking shit again. Lego Fortnite is so bad.

context_findings.summary: Kaze has successfully set up a multistream to both YouTube and Twitch using Restream, noting that the combined viewership is higher than his previous YouTube-only streams.

badub.summary: Badub has already composed the music for the current level (Oily Boily Bay) and others, and Kaze is very pleased with the quality of the work.
badub.quote: We already have songs for all these areas from Badub. And the songs are a banger.

key_stories.title: Creating the 3D 'Board the Platforms' Background
key_stories.summary: Kaze needed to create the background for the Smash 64-themed level. His initial idea proved flawed, so he pivoted to a more creative and technical solution involving modeling the background as giant spheres with cutouts, resulting in a visually dynamic and performant 3D version of the classic backdrop.
key_stories.challenge: Replicating the iconic 'Board the Platforms' background from Smash 64 in 3D in a way that was visually impressive and performant on N64 hardware.
key_stories.process: Kaze's first idea was to use many individual, semi-transparent square planes. He quickly realized this would have performance issues and didn't look right. After abandoning that, he conceived a new plan: creating a giant UV sphere, 'drawing' the shapes on it in Blender, and deleting the negative space. He implemented this for three different colored layers, debugged a rotation issue, and added a slow spin to each layer.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze successfully created a multi-layered, rotating skybox by cutting shapes out of several large spheres. This new method was more performant and achieved the desired high-quality, 3D parallax effect he was aiming for.
key_stories.key_quote: No, no, no, look I have THE idea. The best one yet.

key_stories.title: Live-Coding Camera Control Feedback
key_stories.summary: After receiving viewer feedback about the camera controls being difficult for precise movements, Kaze debated the design philosophy before live-coding an adjustment. He tweaked the camera's acceleration curve to find a better compromise between two different playstyles.
key_stories.challenge: A viewer provided feedback that the d-pad camera controls were not suitable for making small, precise adjustments because of the built-in acceleration.
key_stories.process: Kaze first explained his rationale: the camera was designed to serve both as a slow, main camera for casual players and for quick adjustments. Acknowledging the user's point, he then went into the code, changed the base velocity and acceleration values, recompiled the game, and tested the new feel live on stream.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze implemented a new acceleration curve for the camera controls on the spot. He felt the adjustment was a good compromise that still served both casual players and those needing precise control, deciding to keep the change for now.
key_stories.key_quote: It can work as both. If you want to make precise adjustments, the smoothing messes up. And if you want to use it as a main camera button, it all starts frustrating. I am using it as both, and it works for me.
